content: In #11794, @Yaël Dillies defines strictly convex spaces. I took the liberty to change [semi_normed_group E] assumption to [normed_group E] because otherwise it is impossible for this definition to be true.
I've started writing lemmas about strictly convex spaces, and I can say practically nothing without assuming E to be a real normed space.
So, do we ever need this definition for some other field?
I guess, it may be useful for rational numbers but our lemmas like docs#interior_closed_ball only work in a real normed space.
I thought about this a lot and it seems to me that interior_closed_ball could be generalized to a ℝ-compatible action. I told @Anatole Dedecker about this already.
Do you know if there are other relevant examples than real vector spaces?
I was thinking nnreal-vector spaces, eg the space of measures.
I've never seen strict convexity arguments in this kind of context, but I can certainly imagine they could be useful.
But measure α is not a normed_space ... and we don't have normed nnreal modules anyway.
I suggest that we deal with real normed spaces for now, then generalize to nnreal if needed.
So, what should we do with the "field" argument? The PR is otherwise ready for review.
